meal_plan: Breakfast: Oatmeal with berries and nuts
Lunch: Grilled chicken salad with quinoa
Dinner: Baked salmon with roasted vegetables

Breakfast: Akki Roti with Egg Curry. A crispy rice flour flatbread (akki roti) flavored with cumin, coriander, and grated coconut, served with a spicy Karnataka-style egg curry made with onions, tomatoes, and aromatic spices like Byadagi chili.

Lunch: Bisi Bele Bath with Boiled Egg & Kosambari. A hearty one-pot dish of rice, lentils, and vegetables cooked with a special spice blend (bisi bele bath powder), tempered with ghee. Served with a protein-rich boiled egg and kosambari (a cooling moong dal salad with cucumber and coconut).

Dinner: Ragi Mudde with Soppina Saru & Egg Palya. Soft finger millet balls (ragi mudde) served with nutritious greens broth (soppina saru) made with amaranth or spinach, and a side of egg palya (scrambled eggs with onions, green chilies, and curry leaves).

Breakfast: Kesaribath with Boiled Egg. Kesaribath is a traditional Karnataka sweet dish made from semolina (rava), ghee, sugar, and flavored with saffron and cardamom. This breakfast is often served during festivals and special occasions. Paired with a boiled egg for protein, it provides a hearty start to the day.

Lunch: Obattu with Egg-based Palya and Majjige Huli. Obattu is a sweet flatbread made from whole wheat flour, jaggery, and chana dal, stuffed with a sweet filling. It is served with an egg-based palya (stir-fry) and majjige huli, a tangy yogurt-based curry with vegetables and spices. This meal is balanced and nutritious, perfect for lunch.

Dinner: Neer Dosa with Egg Curry and Green Chutney. Neer Dosa is a light and soft, crepe-like dosa made from rice batter, requiring no fermentation. It pairs wonderfully with a flavorful egg curry made with coconut milk, spices, and a side of green chutney made from coriander and mint. This meal is light yet satisfying, ideal for dinner.

Breakfast: Benne Dosa with Egg Bhurji. Benne Dosa is a crispy, buttery rice and lentil crepe from Karnataka, traditionally made with generous amounts of ghee (clarified butter). It is served with Egg Bhurji, a spiced scrambled egg dish flavored with onions, tomatoes, green chilies, and curry leaves.

Lunch: Mysore Masala Dosa with Egg Kurma. Mysore Masala Dosa is a popular Karnataka dish where a thin, crispy dosa is filled with a spicy potato masala and topped with a tangy, red chutney. It is paired with Egg Kurma, a creamy coconut-based curry with boiled eggs, aromatic spices, and herbs.

Dinner: Set Dosa with Egg Saaru. Set Dosa is a soft, spongy, and slightly fermented rice-lentil crepe, typically served in sets of three. It is accompanied by Egg Saaru, a tangy and spicy Karnataka-style broth made with tamarind, tomatoes, and boiled eggs, flavored with Byadagi chili and spices.

Breakfast: Pundi (Steamed Rice Dumplings) with Egg Bhurji. Pundi is a Mangalorean specialty made from rice flour, shaped into soft dumplings, and steamed. It is served with spicy egg bhurji (scrambled eggs cooked with onions, tomatoes, green chilies, and curry leaves). This breakfast is hearty and energizing, perfect for starting the day.

Lunch: Jolada Roti with Egg Palya & Majjige. Jolada Roti is a North Karnataka staple—a gluten-free flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour. It is served with egg palya (a dry stir-fry of eggs, onions, and spices) and majjige (a cooling yogurt-based curry with cucumber and coconut). This meal is balanced with protein, fiber, and probiotics.

Dinner: Uppittu (Upma) with Egg Curry & Mosaru Bajji. Uppittu is a savory semolina porridge cooked with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and vegetables. It is paired with a mild coconut-based egg curry and mosaru bajji (a yogurt-based salad with chopped onions and green chilies). This light yet satisfying dinner is popular in Karnataka households.

Breakfast: Mysore Pak with Egg Poha. Mysore Pak, a rich and decadent sweet made from gram flour, ghee, and sugar, is paired with a savory egg poha — flattened rice cooked with turmeric, onions, green chilies, and scrambled eggs. This combination offers a balance of sweet and savory flavors, perfect for breakfast.

Lunch: Vangi Bath with Egg Rasam. Vangi Bath is a flavorful rice dish made with brinjal (eggplant), aromatic spices, and tamarind, served with egg rasam — a tangy and spicy broth made with tomatoes, tamarind, boiled eggs, and spices like cumin and pepper. A traditional Karnataka meal that is both hearty and nutritious.

Dinner: Haalbai with Egg Palya. Haalbai is a traditional Karnataka dessert made with rice, coconut milk, and jaggery, flavored with cardamom. It is served with egg palya — a spiced scrambled egg dish cooked with onions, green chilies, and curry leaves. A comforting and nutritious dinner option.

Breakfast: Jolada Rotti with Egg Tambli. A staple in Bagalkot, Jolada Rotti is a thin, unleavened flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour, known for its rustic texture and earthy flavor. It's paired with Egg Tambli, a cooling yogurt-based curry with boiled eggs, coconut, and mild spices like cumin and green chilies. This combo is popular for its simplicity and energy-boosting properties, perfect for mornings in the arid regions of North Karnataka.

Lunch: Huggi with Egg Palya and Badane Ennegai. Huggi is a comforting rice-and-moong dal porridge flavored with ghee, cumin, and black pepper—a Bagalkot favorite for its digestibility. It's served with Egg Palya (spiced scrambled eggs with onions and curry leaves) and Badane Ennegai (stuffed brinjal curry), where baby eggplants are stuffed with a paste of peanuts, coconut, and spices. This meal reflects the region's love for hearty, spice-infused dishes.

Dinner: Khara Pongal with Egg Kootu. Khara Pongal, a savory version of the classic rice-lentil dish, is tempered with ghee, cashews, and curry leaves—a beloved dinner in Bagalkot for its warmth and simplicity. It's paired with Egg Kootu, a creamy coconut-lentil stew with boiled eggs, flavored with turmeric and mustard seeds. This meal is often enjoyed during cooler evenings for its soothing qualities.

Breakfast: Jolada Roti with Chutney and Yogurt. Jolada Roti, a traditional flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour, is a staple breakfast in Bagalkot. It is served with spicy chutney made from groundnuts, garlic, and green chilies, along with a side of fresh yogurt. This meal is popular for its rustic taste and nutritional value, providing sustained energy for the day.

Lunch: Benne Chutney Anna (Butter Rice) with Sambar and Raitha. Benne Chutney Anna is a fragrant rice dish cooked with ghee, tempered with curry leaves, and mixed with a spicy coconut and red chili chutney. It is served with sambar (a lentil and vegetable stew) and cucumber raitha. This meal is a local favorite for its rich flavors and balanced nutrition.

Dinner: Kadlebele Payasa (Chana Dal Dessert) with Jeera Rice. Kadlebele Payasa is a traditional dessert from Bagalkot made with chana dal (split Bengal gram), jaggery, coconut milk, and cardamom. It is served with light jeera rice (cumin-flavored rice). This sweet and savory combination is a comforting end to the day, often prepared during festivals and family gatherings.

Breakfast: Jolada Rotti with Chutney. Jolada Rotti, a traditional flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour, is a staple in Bagalkot and the entire North Karnataka region. It is typically served with a spicy green chutney made from cilantro, mint, and green chilies. This breakfast is light yet filling and is popular for its simplicity and health benefits.

Lunch: Enne Badane (Stuffed Brinjal Curry) with Akki Rotti. Enne Badane is a flavorful curry made with brinjals (eggplants) stuffed with a mix of spices, peanuts, and coconut. It is served with Akki Rotti, a rice flour flatbread. This dish is a local favorite in Bagalkot due to its rich taste and use of locally available ingredients.

Dinner: Kempu Saaru with Rice and Kosambari. Kempu Saaru, a tangy and spicy red lentil soup, is a staple in North Karnataka households, including Bagalkot. It is served with steamed rice and Kosambari, a refreshing salad made with soaked lentils, cucumber, and carrots. This meal is wholesome and comforting, often enjoyed as a dinner staple.

Breakfast: Ragi Mudde with Sambar. Ragi Mudde (finger millet balls) is a staple breakfast in Gadag and across Karnataka. It is known for its simplicity and high nutritional value. Served with Sambar (a lentil-based vegetable stew), this dish provides a fulfilling and energizing start to the day. Ragi is locally grown and widely consumed in Gadag due to its climate.

Lunch: Jowar Roti with Eggplant Palya and Curd. Jowar Roti (sorghum flatbread) is a popular choice in Gadag, paired with Eggplant Palya (a dry eggplant stir-fry) and curd. This meal is hearty and reflects the agricultural heritage of the region, where jowar and eggplant are commonly grown. The combination offers a balance of flavors and textures.

Dinner: Masala Omelette with Akki Roti and Tomato Chutney. A simple yet flavorful dinner option, Masala Omelette (spiced egg omelette) is paired with Akki Roti (rice flatbread) and Tomato Chutney. Eggs are a great source of protein, while Akki Roti is a traditional Karnataka dish made from rice flour. This meal is light yet nutritious and is a favorite among locals.

Breakfast: Mysore Pesarattu. A gluten-free crepe made from green gram (moong dal), rice, and spices, cooked on a traditional iron griddle. This dish is popular in Gadag for its light yet filling nature, and it provides a good source of plant-based protein and fiber.

Lunch: Huggi. A comforting rice and moong dal porridge cooked with ghee, cumin, and black pepper. Huggi is a staple in Gadag households, especially during festivals, and is rich in carbohydrates, protein, and healthy fats, making it a wholesome meal.

Dinner: Menaskai. A tangy and spicy curry made with tamarind, jaggery, and a blend of Karnataka spices, served with steamed rice. Menaskai is a traditional dish in Gadag, known for its bold flavors and nutritional benefits, including antioxidants and vitamins from tamarind and spices.

Breakfast: Jolada Rotti with Chutney. Jolada Rotti is a traditional flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour, a staple in Bagalkot. It is served with a spicy chutney made from peanuts, garlic, and Byadagi chili. This dish is popular for its simplicity and high fiber content, promoting digestion and providing sustained energy.

Lunch: Karnataka-Style Vegetable Khichdi. This hearty one-pot dish combines rice, lentils, and a medley of local vegetables like carrots, beans, and eggplant, cooked with aromatic spices and ghee. Popular in Bagalkot for its comforting taste and nutritional balance, it provides a rich source of protein, fiber, and essential vitamins.

Dinner: Nuchinunde with Saaru. Nuchinunde are steamed lentil dumplings made from a blend of chana dal, urad dal, and spices, served with a tangy saaru (broth) made from tamarind and tomatoes. A staple in Bagalkot, this dish is rich in protein and antioxidants, making it a light yet nourishing dinner option.

Breakfast: Kadubu with Chicken Curry. Kadubu is a steamed rice dumpling made from rice flour and shaped into small cups, a traditional breakfast in Bagalkot. It is served with a flavorful chicken curry cooked with coconut milk, onions, tomatoes, and local spices. This dish provides a balance of carbohydrates and protein, making it a hearty start to the day.

Lunch: Jolada Roti with Mutton Saaru. Jolada Roti is a flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour, a staple in Bagalkot. It is paired with Mutton Saaru, a spicy and tangy mutton broth made with tamarind, tomatoes, and Byadagi chili. This meal is rich in protein, fiber, and essential nutrients, reflecting the region's agricultural heritage and culinary traditions.

Dinner: Navane Pongal with Egg Kuzhambu. Navane Pongal is a comforting dish made from foxtail millet, ghee, and black pepper, a traditional dinner option in Bagalkot. It is served with Egg Kuzhambu, a tangy and spicy egg curry cooked with tamarind, tomatoes, and local spices. This meal is high in protein, iron, and healthy fats, ideal for a nutritious evening meal.

Breakfast: Jolada Rotti with Peanut Chutney. A staple in Bagalkot, this dish consists of jowar (sorghum) flatbread served with spicy peanut chutney. The rotti is dry-roasted on a tava, while the chutney is made with roasted peanuts, garlic, and red chilies. Rich in fiber and protein, it provides sustained energy for the day.

Lunch: Benne Dose with Sambar. A Bagalkot specialty, these crispy rice-lentil crepes are cooked in generous amounts of local butter (benne) and served with tangy sambar made with tur dal, tamarind, and local vegetables. The fermentation process enhances digestion, while the dish provides complex carbs and plant-based proteins.

Dinner: Huggi (Karnataka-style Pongal). A comforting one-pot meal of rice and moong dal cooked with ghee, cumin, and black pepper. This Bagalkot version often includes local jaggery for subtle sweetness. Easy to digest yet nutritious, it provides complete proteins and is traditionally eaten for light evening meals.
